thread.title: NASA rates Indonesian fires worst on record | The Australian
thread.title_full: NASA rates Indonesian fires worst on record | The Australian

author: AFP
title: NASA rates Indonesian fires worst on record | The Australian
text:
Malaysia, Singapore and large expanses of Indonesia have ­suffered for weeks from acrid smoke billowing from fires on plantations and peatlands that are being illegally cleared by burning.
Scientists predict the outbreak could surpass 1997, when out-of-control forest fires sent pollution soaring to record highs in an environmental disaster that cost an estimated $US9 billion ($13bn).
If the forecast dry conditions persist, the region could be enveloped in even denser smog, exacerbating a crisis that grounded flights, closed schools and ­afflicted tens of thousands of people with respiratory problems.
“Conditions in Singapore and southeastern Sumatra are tracking close to 1997,” said Robert Field, a Columbia University scientist based at NASA’s Goddard Institute for Space Studies.
“If the forecasts for a longer dry season hold, this suggests 2015 will rank among the most ­severe events on record.”
Herry Purnomo of the Centre for International Forestry Research said the dry season was not expected to peak in Sumatra until next month: “It’s not over yet.”
The Global Fire Emissions Database estimates 600 million tonnes of greenhouse gases have been released as a result of this year’s fires — equivalent to Germany’s entire annual output.
AFP
